Today and every day, we must continue to honor their legacy by protecting the very democracy they fought to defend.

1479093344391344134.text: Today, I encourage all members of the public to take a moment of silence to remember the courage, bravery and sacrifice those officers and many others demonstrated during that tragic day.

1479093342621343744.text:
We also tragically saw several officers lose their lives in its aftermath, including Capitol Police Officers Brian Sicknick and Howie Liebengood, and Metropolitan Police Officers Jeffrey Smith, Gunther Hashida and Kyle DeFreytag.

They were heroes.

1479093338926157824.text:
Officers like Daniel Hodges, who was violently attacked and nearly crushed to death while attempting to block hundreds of insurrectionists from entering the Capitol.

https://t.co/EOOOX5Q89b

1479093336690544645.text:
Without the Washington, D.C. and Capitol Police officers protecting us that day, this act of democracy would never have been possible.

More than 140 officers were physically harmed while defending our democracy that day.

1479093334257905672.text: And yet, even with the violence and trauma endured that day, I know our nation will prevail. It’s the same reason why at the late hours of that same night, we did not go home but instead, reconvened to certify the election of Joe Biden as the next President of the United States.

1479093332093587462.text:
January 6th, 2021 was undoubtedly one of the darkest days in modern American history, one that illustrated just how fragile our democracy can be.

It showed us first-hand what happens when inciteful, dangerous rhetoric from our public leaders goes unchecked.

1479093329996484614.text:
A mob vandalized, desecrated and forced their way into the U.S. Capitol in an attempt to stop lawmakers from holding up the will of the American people.

They failed.

1479093326557204491.text:
One year removed from the deadly January 6th insurrection, I still remain in disbelief from the events that took place.

Three days into being sworn in, I found myself sheltering my staff in our office away from violent domestic terrorists.

1468691383259127809.text:
The adoption of fire sprinklers in the last 40 years has led to an almost 50% reduction in fire deaths in the US.

Yet, we continue to see far too many firefighter and resident deaths that are caused by fires spreading in older high-rise buildings due to a lack of sprinklers.

1468691381464051715.text:
The current tax code treats fire sprinklers the same as plumbing and their costs are depreciated over 39 years.

Our High-Rise Fire Sprinkler Incentive Act simply decreases this cost recovery to 15 years, incentivizing building owners to install fire sprinklers.

1468691379534680064.text:
🚨BIG NEWS: I joined @BillPascrell & @RepJohnKatko today in introducing bipartisan legislation to protect our firefighters.

1458803622049992708.text:
I'm proud to say we've made progress on this bill.

In the defense budget that the House passed this fall, we were able to secure an amendment that would direct the @DeptofDefense to conduct a study on the herbicide agent exposure in the Panama Canal Zone.
https://t.co/k44oaIhmxP

1458803621202739210.text:
Under this bill, veterans who served in or near the Panama Canal Zone would be granted presumptive herbicide exposure status.

That means they could finally receive federal benefits and disability compensation from the U.S. Department of Veteran Affairs.

1458803620116369414.text:
This is personal to me because I come from a family that served in the military.

We have a fundamental obligation to honor our veterans by providing them with the care they deserve.

That's why I introduced the bipartisan Panama Canal Zone Veterans Act w/ @RepMariaSalazar.

1458803619147440134.text: Even though VA coverage is offered for those who served in Vietnam, the Korean DMZ and on the base in Thailand — PCZ veterans do not qualify and have never been given the opportunity to be heard.

1458803617918603269.text:
Now, he lives without the use of a pancreas after developing diabetes and growing 14 stones inside his pancreas.

He filed a claim with the VA for help after locating PROOF of U.S. exports of herbicides to PCZ.

Twice, the VA has denied his claim for disability compensation. https://t.co/Hu1l2TfM1A

1458803613946556427.text:
Gene is an Army veteran who served in the Panama Canal Zone (PCZ) from 1974 to 1977. He remembers how something was sprayed to defoliate the jungle nearly every day.

After his service ended, Gene's health deteriorated. And for over 20 years, he was in and out of the hospital. https://t.co/4QW5B9a2aG

1458803610230341640.text:
This #VeteransDay, let's talk about our Panama Canal Zone veterans.

Many developed severe health problems after being exposed to deadly herbicides like Agent Orange. To this day, they don't receive federal benefits to cover these issues.

Gene Tornoe is one of those veterans🧵👇 https://t.co/OXFXBIe2BY
